title: Jehoram's War with Moab
shortSummary: This chapter recounts King Jehoram of Israel's alliance with Jehoshaphat of Judah and the king of Edom to fight against the rebellious Moabites. Despite dire circumstances, the prophet Elisha provides divine guidance, resulting in a miraculous provision of water and a victorious campaign. The chapter highlights God's sovereignty, the power of prophetic intercession, and the consequences of idolatry.
timeline: c. 850 BC - Reign of Jehoram of Israel and Jehoshaphat of Judah

keyCharacters.name: Jehoram
keyCharacters.description: Son of Ahab and king of Israel who leads the coalition against Moab but continues in the sins of Jeroboam.

keyCharacters.name: Jehoshaphat
keyCharacters.description: King of Judah who allies with Jehoram and Edom, seeking the LORD’s guidance through the prophet Elisha.

keyCharacters.name: Elisha
keyCharacters.description: The prophet of the LORD who provides divine direction and performs a miracle to sustain the allied armies.

keyCharacters.name: Mesha
keyCharacters.description: King of Moab who rebels against Israel and ultimately sacrifices his son to try to secure victory.

keyCharacters.name: King of Edom
keyCharacters.description: An ally who joins Israel and Judah in the military campaign against Moab.

definitions.definition: A Canaanite deity worshiped through idolatry; Jehoram removed the image of Baal made by his father Ahab.
A musician or player of stringed instruments; Elisha requested a minstrel to play before receiving a prophetic revelation.
A sacrificial offering completely consumed by fire, symbolizing dedication and atonement.
A fortified city with walls for protection, significant in ancient warfare.

outline.heading: Jehoram’s Reign and Moab’s Rebellion
outline.description: Jehoram begins his reign over Israel, continues in idolatry but removes Baal’s image. Moab, previously a tributary, rebels after Ahab’s death, setting the stage for conflict.

outline.heading: Alliance and March through Edom
outline.description: Jehoram allies with Jehoshaphat and Edom’s king to fight Moab, but they face a severe water shortage, causing fear of defeat.

outline.heading: Seeking God’s Guidance through Elisha
outline.description: Jehoshaphat urges consultation with the LORD. Elisha initially rebukes Jehoram but agrees to help because of Jehoshaphat, prophesying a miraculous provision of water and victory.

outline.heading: Miraculous Provision and Victory over Moab
outline.description: Water miraculously appears, deceiving Moabites into thinking the allied kings are dead. Israel and allies defeat Moab, destroying cities and resources.

outline.heading: Mesha’s Desperate Sacrifice and Aftermath
outline.description: Mesha sacrifices his heir to try to turn the tide, provoking divine indignation and causing the allied kings to withdraw.

application: Seek God’s guidance in difficult circumstances through prayer and godly counsel, as Jehoshaphat did by consulting Elisha.
Trust in God’s provision even when natural resources or circumstances seem impossible, remembering His power to provide miraculously.
Avoid the sins of idolatry and partial obedience, recognizing that incomplete faithfulness leads to ongoing spiritual failure.
Recognize the seriousness of sin and its consequences, as seen in Moab’s rebellion and Mesha’s tragic sacrifice.

keyVerses.text: But now bring me a minstrel. And it came to pass, when the minstrel played, that the hand of the LORD came upon him.
keyVerses.significance: This verse shows how God’s presence and power come through prophetic means, preparing for divine revelation.

keyVerses.text: For thus saith the LORD, Ye shall not see wind, neither shall ye see rain; yet that valley shall be filled with water, that ye may drink, both ye, and your cattle, and your beasts.
keyVerses.significance: A powerful promise of God’s supernatural provision despite natural conditions, demonstrating His sovereignty over creation.

keyVerses.text: Then he took his eldest son that should have reigned in his stead, and offered him for a burnt offering upon the wall. And there was great indignation against Israel: and they departed from him, and returned to their own land.
keyVerses.significance: This tragic act reveals the desperation of rebellion against God’s people and the moral consequences that follow.
